variant.question: The maximum number of unrelated items that can be stored in working memory is..

options.text: about 7 items.
unlimited.
only 3 items, on average.
about 30 items.

variant.question: Mnemonics are used in aviation because they..

options.text: help to increase retention of information.
increase motivation.
are a tool for avoiding illusions.
increase response time.

variant.question:
A pilot flying a twin-engine aircraft is communicating with ATC because there is proximate traffic. While he is looking out for the traffic, he performs a quick scan of his instrument panel and sees that the oil pressure on one engine is low.
In which kind of memory will the information about the oil pressure level be kept and how long will it stay there?

options.text: Working memory; up to 20 seconds
Sensory memory; a fracture of a second
Short-term memory; a few minutes
Long-term memory; indefinitely

variant.question: If a pilot has to perform two tasks requiring the allocation of cognitive resources

options.text: the sharing of resources causes performance on each task to be reduced.
the only way of not seeing performance tail off is to switch to knowledge-based mode for the two tasks.
a person reaches his limits as from simultaneous tasks, and performance will then tail off.
the only way of not seeing performance tail off is to switch to rule-based mode for the two tasks.

variant.question: Which statement about Long Term Memory (LTM) is correct?

options.text: Unless an item is recalled regularly, it becomes more difficult to retrieve from the LTM store.
Any item can be recalled from the LTM with ease as long as it has been stored correctly.
Facts can be stored in the episodic memory instead of the semantic memory. Careful attention in learning will counteract this error.
Recent events can be stored in the semantic memory instead of the episodic memory. Careful attention to detail will counteract this error.

variant.question: Which of the following is the best definition of episodic memory? It is the memory of events that are held in the..

options.text: long term memory and can be influenced by suggestion.
short term memory and can be influenced by suggestion.
long term memory and can be influenced by the meaning of words and language.
short term memory and can be influenced by the meaning of words and language.

variant.question: As you are flying through bad weather, you try to remember the temperature below which you have to be aware of icing. This value has been told to you a week ago in your company's winter operations course. Name the type(s) of memory involved in the process of saving and recalling that information.

options.text: All memory types. The information is perceived while in the sensory memory, transferred to the short-term memory and evaluated, and then moved to the longterm memory to keep it.
The short-term memory. It is responsible for keeping information for a short period of time, in this case for one week.
The long-term memory. All other types of memory last for only a few minutes.
The sensory memory and the long-term memory. The value is perceived and evaluated in the sensory memory during the training course, and then transferred directly into the long-term memory.

variant.question: Working memory enables us, for example, to..

options.text: remember a clearance long enough to write it down.
ignore messages for other aircraft.
remember our own name.
store a large amount of visual information for about 0.5 seconds.

variant.question: Which of the following statements about long-term memory are correct? - Information is stored in the Semantic, Episodic and Procedural memories. - The period of time for which information is retained is limited by the frequency with which this same information is used. - It processes information quickly and has an effective mode of access in real time. - Ease and speed of access is dependent upon, to a large extent, the frequency with which the information is recalled.

Which of the following answers are correct concerning the Long Term Memory? - Long Term memory can be affected by expectation and suggestion. - Long Term Memory is also known as the Working Memory. - Long Term Memory is limited to plus or minus 7 pieces of disassociated pieces of information. - Long Term Memory is where Motor Programmes (skills) are kept.

options.text: 1 only

variant.question: Working memory..

options.text: is sensitive to interruptions, which may erase all or some of its contents.
varies considerably in size between an experienced pilot and a novice pilot.
is unlimited in size.
is unlimited in duration.

variant.question: With regard to short-term memory, we can say that it..

options.text: holds information for immediate use, and is limited in its capacity for storing and retaining data.
holds information for immediate use, and is limited in its capacity to retain data but not in its capacity to store data.
stores mainly procedural knowledge (skills).
is a stable form of working memory, and therefore is not sensitive to disturbances.

variant.question:
**Long-term memory is an essential component of the pilots knowledge and expertise.** 
 Which of the following statements is correct regarding Long term memory?

options.text: It is desirable to pre-activate knowledge stored in long-term memory to have it available when required.
The recovery of information from long-term memory is immediate and easy.
Its capacity is limited.
Long-term memory stores knowledge on a temporary basis only.

variant.question: A private pilot is waiting for a delayed passenger. When they finally depart, the pilot decides to do a checklist from memory instead of actually reading it. In flight, he notices that he has missed an item from the checklist. This is....

options.text: A violation, followed by a lapse.
A slip, followed by a violation.
A knowledge-based error, followed by a slip.
A rule-based error, followed by a lapse.

variant.question: Long-term memory is an essential component of the pilots knowledge and expertise.

options.text: It is desirable to pre-activate knowledge stored in long-term memory to have it available when required.
Long-term memory stores knowledge on a temporary basis.
The recovery of information from long-term memory is immediate and easy.
The capacity of long-term memory is limited.

variant.question: The main limit(s) of long-term memory is/are:

options.text: data retrieval as a result from a loss of access to the stored information.
the quantity of data which may be stored.
the instantaneous inputting in memory of all information collected during the day, which comes to saturate it.
the data storage time.

variant.question: Which of the following characteristics apply to short-term memory?

options.text: It is limited in time and size.
It is unlimited in time and limited in size.
It is limited in time and unlimited in size.
It is stable and insensitive to disturbances.

variant.question: The working short term memory can store a maximum of approximately...

options.text: 9 bits of information
12 bits of information
5 bits of information
unlimited bits of information

variant.question:
Which items are correct as regards the main limits of short term memory? It is 
1 very sensitive to interruptions and interference 
2 difficult to access 
3 limited in size 
4 that information is lost within approximately 20 seconds unless it is actively or deliberately placed into the long term memory

options.text: 2 and 3
2 and 4

options.text: The last transponder code provided by ATC which is not set on the transponder.
The last transponder code provided by ATC and set on the transponder.

options.text: A transponder code, up until the pilot enters the code into the transponder.
The FL set on the autopilot.

options.text: 20 seconds.
1 hour.
12 minutes.

options.text: episodic memory.
semantic memory.
long term memory.

variant.question: Which of the following statements about long-term memory are correct? - Information is stored there in the form of descriptive, rule-based and schematic knowledge. - The period of time for which information is retained is limited by the frequency with which this same information is used. - It processes information quickly and has an effective mode of access in real time. - Pre-activation of necessary knowledge will allow for a reduction in access time.

 The working short term memory can store a maximum of approximately...

options.text: 5 bits of information.
12 bits of information.

unlimited bits of information.

variant.question: What are the main limits of short-term memory? - Very sensitive to interruptions and interference - Difficult to access - Limited in size - Information is usually lost within approximately 20 seconds.

options.text: episodic memory.

variant.question: Long-term memory is influenced by

options.text: experience, repetition, suggestion, desires, and expectations.
intelligence, experience, gender, suggestion, and expectations.

variant.question: Short term memory retains a larger amount of information with..

options.text: a process called “chunking”.
signal colours.
a lower intensity of information.
every repetition.

variant.question:
Which option correctly lists, from the items shown below, cognitive effects of stress?

1. excessive haste2. an improvement in memory3. a complete block: action is impossible4. a risk of focusing on a particular aspect5. ease of decision-making6. an increase in the rate of mistakes

options.text: 1, 3, 4, and 6 only
2, 3, 5, and 6 only
1, 2, and 5 only
3, 4, and 5 only

variant.question:
Which of the following is an item of information that is important for a pilot to hold in his/her working memory during a flight?
The 4-digit...

options.text: transponder code assigned by ATC during flight, up to the point when the pilot sets it into the transponder.
radio failure transponder code, when flying in a hostile environment.
emergency transponder code, especially during take-off and final approach.
transponder code that has already been set into the transponder, having been assigned by ATC during the flight.

variant.question: Pilots often use mnemonics to remember multiple words, phrases or sentences (in the correct order if required). This increases the amount of information that can be stored in the...

options.text: Working memory
Procedural memory
Long Term memory
Episodic memory

variant.question: A small aircraft has joined the circuit and is on final approach. Code 4202 is set on the transponder and QNH 1009 on the altimeter. The pilot receives the following message from the Control Tower: "G-ABCD cleared to land, runway 01, wind 350 degrees, ten knots". Which option lists the information that the pilot is expected to hold in working memory at this point?

options.text: The direction (350 degrees) and speed (ten knots) of the wind vector.
The QNH value (1009) that is set into the altimeter.
The 4 digit code assigned by ATC and set into the transponder (4292) prior to entering the ATZ.
The VHF radio frequency of the Control Tower delivering the clearance.

variant.question: What is meant by episodic memory?

options.text: Memory of experienced events, held in the long term memory.
Memory of events, held in the short term memory.
Memory of information, held in the short term memory.
Memory of information, held in the long term memory.

variant.question: What is a skill?

options.text: The capability of completing task requiring knowledge and training.
The capability of completing task requiring knowledge but no training.
The capability of performing any task which doesn't require knowledge or training.
The capability of completing a task requiring training but no knowledge

variant.question: Which of the following is an item of information that is important for a pilot to hold in their working memory during a flight?

options.text: The 4 digit squawk code assigned by ATC during flight, up to the point when the pilot sets it into the transponder.
The 4 digit radio failure squawk code, when flying in a hostile environment.
The 4 digit emergency squawk code, especially during take-off and final approach.
The 4 digit squawk code that has already been set into the transponder, having been assigned by ATC during the flight.

variant.question: State the typical retention time of the working memory:

options.text: five to seven items within 30 seconds without rehearsing.
seven to nine items within 30 seconds with rehearsing.
seven to nine items within 30 seconds without rehearsing.
five to seven items within 30 seconds with rehearsing.

variant.question: Which statement concerning working memory is correct? Working memory is

options.text: sensitive to interruptions and limited in size.
unlimited in duration and sensitive to interruptions.
insensitive to interferences and unlimited in duration.
limited in size and insensitive to interferences.

variant.question: Mental training is helpful to improve flying skills:

options.text: at all levels of flying proficiency.
only for instructor pilots.
only at a certain level of flying experience.
only for student pilots.

variant.question:
A pilot is approaching the destination airfield. Their radio is tuned to the aerodrome frequency 128.125 MHz, the transponder is set to 4272 as instructed and the altimeter is set to the local QNH of 1002 hPa. ATC issues the following clearance: “G-ABCD, surface wind 130 degrees, 5 knots, cleared to land runway 09.”
The following information is currently stored in the pilot’s working memory?

options.text: Wind 130 degrees, 5 knots
Squawk 4272
QNH 1002 hPa
Communication frequency 128.125 MHz

variant.question: The main limitation of the long term memory is

options.text: that unless information is accessed from time to time, its retrieval can be difficult.
the data-storage time.
that if enough information is entered at the same time, saturation may take place.
the quantity of data which may be stored.

variant.question: Information stays in the short-term memory:

options.text: about 20 seconds.
from 5 to 10 minutes.
less than 1 second.
around 24 hours.

variant.question: To facilitate and reduce the time taken to access information in long-term memory, it is helpful to:

options.text: mentally rehearse information before it is needed.
avoid to rehearse information which we know we will need soon.
learn and store data in a logical and structured way.
structure irrelevant information as much as possible before committing it to memory.

variant.question: Concerning the capacity of the human long-term memory:

options.text: its storage capacity is unlimited.
it is structurally limited in terms of storage time but not in terms of capacity.
its mode of storing information is passive, making memory searches effective.
it is structurally limited in terms of storage capacity, but unlimited in terms of storage time.

variant.question: Concentration is essential for pilots:

options.text: however, capacity of concentration is limited.
vigilance is all that is required to be attentive.
it only takes a little willpower to increase ones capacity of concentration without limits.
all intellectual processes, including very routine ones, make demands on resources and therefore on ones concentration.

variant.question: With regard to the practice of English, which of the following statements is correct?

options.text: All pilots should have a sound understanding of English because it is safer to adhere to the common language chosen by the aeronautical world.
The composition of every crew should be geared to a command of the official aeronautical language of the destination country.
It is necessary and sufficient to have a command of any of the official languages of the ICAO.
Be familiar with normal procedures in English since only this allows for effective management of any flight’s communication.

variant.question: With regard to the practice of English, which of the following statements is correct?

options.text: All pilots should master it because the aeronautical world needs one common language.
It is necessary and sufficient to have a command of any of the official languages of the ICAO.
The composition of every crew should be geared to a command of the official aeronautical language of the destination country.
Be familiar with normal procedures in English since only this allows for effective management of any flight's communication.

variant.question: A pilot receives a clearance from ATC, meanwhile he scans his instruments, and quickly notices that the temperature is high on one engine. What does he exhibit?

options.text: Divided Attention.
Visual memory of approximately 1 second, which enables him to react consciously to the reading.
Daytime scanning technique.
Visual memory which lasts up to 20 seconds, enabling him to return to react consciously to the reading.

variant.question: The available cognitive resources of the human brain..

options.text: are limited and make it impossible to perform two attentional tasks at the same time.
are virtually unlimited.
allow for simultaneous operation of twin tasks without any loss of effectiveness.
are limited but make it possible to easily perform several tasks at the same time.

variant.question: For which pilots is mental rehearsal helpful for improving flying skills?

options.text: For pilots at all levels of flying proficiency.
For pilots with only a certain level of flying experience.
For student pilots but not instructors.
For instructor pilots but not students.

variant.question:
An aircraft is approaching an airfield for landing, it has been told to squawk 4292 and has set to the aerodrome QNH of 1002 hPA. The ATC clear the aircraft to land G-ABCD cleared to land runway 09, surface wind 230 5 knots
 What information is stored in working memory?

options.text: Wind information
Ergonomic
SQUAWK CODE
LOCAL QNH

variant.question: The pilot of a multi-engined aircraft is looking out for traffic and also concentrating on following ATC instructions to avoid a traffic conflict. After a very brief look at the instruments, the pilot's eyes automatically focus on the analogue engine gauges. He/she quickly sees that one needle indicates an abnormal oil pressure value for one of the engines. What statement correctly explains how the brain is storing and processing the information from the instruments in the above scenario?

options.text: The visual image of the abnormal value is stored in the sensory store for about 1 second. The pilot automatically reacts by looking at the gauges, and then his/her attention consciously focuses on their indications.

The indications from all the instruments are stored as information in the pilot's working memory. The pilot then consciously and quickly processes the information and decides that one engine's oil pressure value is abnormal.

The attention of the pilot is split between focussing inside the cockpit and looking outside. The indications from the instruments are stored for up to 20 seconds in the visual sensory store, enabling the pilot to process their information while recalling the ATC instructions.

The pilot detects the abnormal value by making a detailed scan of all the instruments, complying with the procedures requiring continuous cross-checking of instruments during flight. His/her selective attention is focussed on all the instruments' values.

variant.question:
Which of the following characteristics apply to short-term memory?
1) It is limited in time and size.
2) It is unlimited in time and limited in size.
3) It is stable and insensitive to disturbances.
4) It is limited in time and unlimited in size.

options.text: blinkered concentration.
environmental capture.
mode capture.
selective attention.

options.text: blinkered concentration.

mode capture.
selective attention.

variant.question: Which of the following is true with reference to semantic memory?

options.text: It is the meaning of words and general knowledge of the world; it lasts for a longer period of time than episodic memory and tends to be more accurate.
It is the meaning of words and general knowledge of the world; it lasts for a longer period of time than episodic memory and tends to be less accurate.
It is the memory of events; it lasts for a longer period of time than episodic memory and tends to be less accurate.
It is the memory of events; it lasts for a longer period of time than episodic memory and tends to be more accurate.

variant.question: Which of the following is true with reference to semantic memory?

options.text: It is the meaning of words and general knowledge of the world; it lasts for a longer period of time and tends to be more accurate than episodic memory.
It is the memory of events; it lasts for a longer period of time than episodic memory and tends to be more accurate.
It is the memory of events; it lasts for a shorter period of time than episodic memory and tends to be less accurate.
It is the meaning of words and general knowledge of the world; it lasts for a shorter period of time than episodic memory and tends to be less accurate.

variant.question:
Getting uneasy will affect:
1) attention.
2) concentration.
3) memory.
4) prudence.
Working memory enables us, for example:

options.text: ignoring or rationalising the stress factor.
a deliberate removal of the stressor.
eliminating the source of the stressor.
taking medicine to relieve the effects of stress.

variant.question: Which of the following statements about long-term memory is correct?

options.text: Information is stored in the Semantic, Episodic, and Procedural memories.
The period of time for which information is retained is limited by the frequency with which this same information is used.
Long-term memory processes information quickly and has an effective mode of access in real time.
Long-term memory stores knowledge on a temporary basis.

variant.question:
Which of the following statements is/are correct?
1) Interesting information is easier to take into consideration for creating a mental picture than boring information.
2) The sequence in which information is presented is also important for the use the pilot makes of it.

options.text: 1 and 2 are both correct.
1 is not correct, 2 is correct.
1 is correct, 2 is not correct.
1 and 2 are both not correct.

variant.question: Name the most common problem of the long-term memory and how would you counteract it?

options.text: Unless an item is recalled regularly, it becomes more and more difficult to retrieve from the LTM store.
Recent events can become muddled in the LTM. Careful attention to detail associated with "memory bench marking" will go a long way towards avoiding this tendency.
Any item can be recalled from the LTM with ease as long as it has been stored correctly.
Facts can be stored in the episodic memory instead of the semantic memory. Careful attention in learning will counteract this error.
